item.title: Taking a ride on a freight train to cover migration to the U.S.
item.description: For decades, migrants have been riding north through Mexico aboard a freight train nicknamed "La Bestia." An NPR reporter hopped on board to ask some migrants why they do it.

item.title: Kurdish militant group PKK declares ceasefire after decades of conflict with Turkey
item.description: Militants from the Kurdistan Workers' Party have declared a ceasefire, in what may represent a significant political breakthrough for Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdoğan.

item.title: Up to 3,000 more U.S. troops are ordered to the border with Mexico
item.description: Up to 3,000 additional troops have been ordered to the U.S.-Mexico border by Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth, the latest in President Trump's efforts to prevent illegal crossings.

item.title: Legendary former NIH director retires from embattled agency
item.description: Dr. Francis Collins is leaving the National Institutes of Health, where he served as director from 2009 to 2021. The agency is facing cutbacks and restrictions under the Trump administration.

item.title: ICE is making more arrests, but critics say some claims don't add up
item.description: Immigration authorities are making more arrests than they did under President Biden. But the Department of Homeland Security's own data shows that they're not keeping pace with White House demands.

item.title: Alabama governor commutes a death row inmate's sentence to life in prison
item.description: Alabama Gov. Kay Ivey commuted the death sentence of Robin "Rocky" Myers to life in prison, saying there were enough questions about his guilt that she could not move forward with his execution.

item.title: These National Park workers say a Trump agency fired them illegally. A judge agrees
